importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, beginning in 2025 and culminating around 2035.

keyTakeAways: Reefline is a 7-mile-long artificial reef project off Miami Beach, designed to restore the island's lost coral habitat and serve as an ecotourism destination.
The project features underwater sculptures made from marine-grade concrete, including 22 cars arranged in a traffic jam, which act as coral carriers.
The coral species used are resilient, locally sourced gorgonians and other soft corals that can withstand disease and warming ocean temperatures.
The project is co-led by artist Ximena Caminos, who is a cultural placemaker and arts curator with experience revitalizing neighborhoods in Buenos Aires and Miami Beach.
Colin Foord, a coral researcher and founder of Coral Morphologic, is responsible for cultivating and transplanting corals to the reef.
The project is partially funded by a $5 million Miami Beach city bond and aims to raise $6 million more for its first phase.
Reefline will include an onshore marine learning center to educate the public about endangered coral reefs.
The project aims to restore a coral reef that once existed off Miami Beach but was lost in the 1970s due to sand replenishment.
Artists like Leandro Ehrlich contribute by creating sculptures that will eventually be overgrown by coral, blending art and marine restoration.
The final phase may feature 57 giant sculpted starfish, potentially becoming a symbol of Miami Beach in the future.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a 7-mile-long artificial reef designed to restore a historic coral habitat lost in the 1970s. The project combines art and science, with artists like Ximena Caminos and Leandro Ehrlich creating underwater sculptures from marine-grade concrete — including 22 cars — that will be colonized by resilient, locally sourced gorgonian corals. Scientists like Colin Foord cultivate and transplant these corals in a nursery, with the hope that over time, the sculptures will become part of a living, vibrant reef. The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and seeks an additional $6 million. It aims to become an ecotourism destination, educational center, and cultural symbol, with a potential future phase featuring 57 giant sculpted starfish. Reefline represents a bold fusion of environmental restoration and artistic innovation.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
